Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2009 03:05PM cd1234 wrote: Hi Cheryl, My husband shaved my head on day 15 after my first treatment. I got sick of wearing a wig or hats, I walked around bald alot!. I just decided it is what it is, and there was not a lot I could do about it! Hang in there sister!
Posts.Title: Hair is leaving the building.... victoriasecret victoriasecret

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2009 03:08PM cd1234 wrote: I love this thread. I follow you all frequently! My hair started growing in after my last round of AC, and kept growing through Taxol. I had a wig, and hats and scarfs, but mostly I just walked around bald. I was more comfortable that way. I actually got very used to the way I looked. When my Taxol hair started growing in, I felt that I looked like a man. Anyhow, My last Taxol was August 13th, and my brows and lashes all fell out a month later. Luckily, they seem to grow fast, so they are now at the point of wearing mascara again. I rarely have to shave my legs, and not a single hair has grown in my armpits. I hope it stays that way! I wish I had a bumper sticker that said "I love Hair". My husband says it would send mixed messages!!! LOL! Take Care All, and happy hair growing!  I LOVE HAIR
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Can anyone tell me when I might feeling some side effects from my estrogen being turned off? I have had a few hot flashes in the night, but nothing like I did during chemo.  Thank you!

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2010 01:25AM cd1234 wrote: Hi Tabatha,  I am glad you are home and feeling great. I am very curious if you notice  any side effects from the lack of estrogen. I think we are the same age based on dx date. I was diagnosed when I was 37 also, I turned 39 a few months ago. I have only had a few hot flashes so far, otherwise I feel great. Take care!
Posts.Title: Oophroectomy (sp) Tabatha00 Alyad

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2010 02:35PM cd1234 wrote: Hi All, Balsie - I am not on Arimidex, I am onTamoxifen. I was told that the continuous eye lash falling out was the Taxol...who knows for sure. All I know is I am over it. I work in a very conservative office, so PJ day might not go over so well...kind of makes me laugh to think what my boss would say if I showed up in PJ's though! When I was going through chemo, my feet got very swollen and I did show up in flip flops one day. No one said a word. I think I came in withou my wig that day also, so they were all scared of me. Mouse6 - Sorry to hear about the positive biopsy. I had a bi-lateral due to the fact that I have ILC and it tends to spread to the other breast. I do not regret my decision at all, but it is a very personal one for each of us. The entire process is very confusing, take your time and ask lots of questions. I remember I used to feel dumb asking questions, but how the heck are we supposed to know...unfortunately, this is new to all of us! Take care all! Crystal
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2010 09:21AM cd1234 wrote: Hi All, I have been lurking on this thread for awhile so I thought I would say hi. I was diagnosed IIa last January at 37 years old. I have and 8 year old son. I had a bilateral with no reconstruction. I went in 2 1/2 weeks ago to begin the reconstruction.  I developed a horrible infection in my right expander and had to have it removed. Now I have to wait another 3 - 4 months to try again.  Balsie- I am with you on the PJ's. They are my favorite outfit. Wish I could wear them to work today because I feel like a train hit me.   My last chemo was August 13th, and I just lost my eyelashes again! Take Care!

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 06:10PM cd1234 wrote: Hi Laurie, The eye patches were pretty noticeable, so I wore loose fitting blouses and cardigans. I wore the badages longer than my PS said I had too, just to be safe. I did not want to take any chances!
Posts.Title: how did your PS protect your new nipples after recon surgery? Laurie08 mtks

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 03:28PM cd1234 wrote: Hi Laurie, My PS had me wear eye bandages. I bought them at Walgreen's. I cut an X in the center of the bandage for the nipple and very gently taped them with paper surgical tape to keep them in place. They worked well.  Take care!
Posts.Title: how did your PS protect your new nipples after recon surgery? Laurie08 mtks

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2009 02:15PM cd1234 wrote: I was in in a different study. I received AC-T and Avastin every third treatment, which means I got 8 doses of Avastin. I had EKG's and MUGA scans done at the beginning, in the middle and at the end of chemo. I had no problems with Avastin at all. The study was a blind study and I was very surprised at the end when I found out that I was indeed receiving Avastin, because of the lack of side effects. That is not to say that I did not have lots of side effects from the AC-T.
